quote: The British Expeditionary Force (BEF) is dispatched to France to reinforce the French army.
explanation: This highlights the early Anglo-French military cooperation and British commitment to the Western Front.

quote: The Allied forces halt the German advance at the First Battle of the Marne.
explanation: This marks a crucial early Allied success, stopping the rapid German advance into France.

quote: The battle also marked the end of mobile warfare.
explanation: This signifies a profound shift from movement to static, positional fighting on the Western Front.

quote: Each side was now building vast defensive trench networks stretching from Switzerland to the North Sea.
explanation: This explains the immediate, physical manifestation of the shift to trench warfare across the front.

quote: The Germans later called this the Kindermord (“child murder”), or more loosely the Massacre of the Innocents.
explanation: This term underscores the devastating human cost, especially among inexperienced German volunteers.

quote: On Christmas Eve 1914, German soldiers on the Western Front began to sing carols and put up Christmas trees along their trenches. This continued into Christmas Day, when soldiers on both sides spontaneously started to walk into no-man’s land.
explanation: This unique event shows a spontaneous, widespread moment of temporary peace and fraternization amidst brutal conflict.

quote: a new form of trench-bound warfare swiftly developed.
explanation: This directly states the emergence of the defining characteristic of the Western Front.

quote: The defensive trench system—resilient even in the face of the huge explosive and destructive power of modern weapons—proved so effective from late 1914 that it totally paralyzed any hope of a war of movement on the Western Front.
explanation: This explains how trench systems fundamentally changed the nature of combat, causing stalemate.

quote: In the end, it took slow, steady attrition to turn the war against the German army and in favor of the Allies.
explanation: This reveals the ultimate long-term strategy and grim reality of how the war was eventually won.

quote: The Committee of Imperial Defence took the claims seriously, and in 1909, the Secret Service Bureau—forerunner of MI5 and MI6—was born.
explanation: This highlights the formal establishment of key intelligence agencies pre-war, showing foresight.

quote: On August 8, 1914, four days after declaring war on Germany, the British government passed its Defence of the Realm Act “for securing public safety.”
explanation: This shows early wartime legislation, granting extensive powers and impacting civilian life.

quote: Consequently, codebreaking evolved rapidly among both the Allies and Central Powers.
explanation: This emphasizes the critical development of signals intelligence as a key aspect of secret warfare.
